Subjects: political poems; advice, to princes; princes, advice to; envoys
_description: Hoccleve’s De Regimine Principum — 780 stanzas rhyme royal.

BodLauMis735.First Lines:
Mvsyng vp on the restles bysynesWhich þat this troubli word
                    hath ay on honde…
BodLauMis735.Last Lines:
…Thi sauour ȝet is full small as I trowBut or oght long I
                    shall te sothe y knaw

BodDig185.First Lines:
Mvsyng vpon the resteles bysynesseThe whitch this trouble world
                    hath ay on hond…
BodDig185.Last Lines:
…To the that all seest of loves servenceThat knoweth he that
                    nothing is hidd fro

BodSelSup53.First Lines:
Knyȝthood a wake þou slepist to longeThi brother see nowe
                    ny deed for mischeef…
BodSelSup53.Last Lines:
…To þee þat al saist of loues feruenceThat knowith
                    he whom no þing is hid fro
BodSelSup53.Attributed Title: Explicit Egidius de Regimine Principum (at the end)

BodAsh40.First Lines:
MUsynge vp on the resteles besynesWiche that this trowbly worlde
                    haþ ay on hondeThat other þinge þan fruite of
                    bytternesseNe ȝeldeth not as y can vndrestonde…
BodAsh40.Last Lines:
…To þee þat al seist of loues feruenceThat knoweth
                    he whom no þing is hid fro
BodAsh40.Attributed Title:
A the end of the poem on f. 97v: Explicit Egidius de regimine
                        Principium. Grace growith aftir gouernaunce.

BodRawD913.First Lines:
Now noble prince þough I be not wyseWel willid am I as I furst
                    yow tolde…
BodRawD913.Last Lines:
…ffor yif þat he that wikkid gost recetteBy such a lord
                    wil honour no thyng sette
BodRawD913.Note:
A fragment: 2185-2212 on recto and 2220-2247 on verso (missing stanza
                    2213-2219). Space at bottom of recto and top verso shows not
                    cropped.

BodRawPoe10.First Lines:
Musynge vp on the restlees bysynesseWhich that this troubly world
                    hath ay on honde…
BodRawPoe10.Last Lines:
…To the that all seiste of loues feruenceThat knowith he wham
                    no thyng ys hid froo

BodRawPoe168.First Lines:
My noble and mighti prince excellentMi lorde the prince o my lorde
                    gracious…
BodRawPoe168.Last Lines:
…To the that al seest of loues feruenceThat knoweth whom no
                    thing is hid fro
BodRawPoe168.Attributed Author:
Here endeth the Boke of gouernaunce of princes that Thomas Hoccleue made.
                    Which is a boke of moraltees and of vertues of highli dispreising lewednesse and
                    vices (at the end).
BodRawPoe168.Attributed Title: Hic incipit liber de regimine principum (f. 1).

BodDou158.First Lines:
[ ]vpon þe restles bisynesse[ ] hiche þat þis world
                    hat ay onhondeThat othir þing þan fruyt of
                    bittirnesse…
BodDou158.Last Lines:
…To þee þat alle seith of loues feruenceþat
                    knoweth he whom noþtnge is hid fro

Bod221.First Lines:
Mvsyng opon the restles besynesWhich þat þis troubly
                    world hath ay on hande…
Bod221.Last Lines:
…Makes full many schippis for to sayleInto þi cofre warme
                    is þine office
Bod221.Note: Ends imperfectly; some folios in the middle mutilated.

CULGg617.First Lines:
[m]using vpon the Restlesse besinesWhich that this troubelouse
                    world hath ay on hond…
CULGg617.Last Lines:
…That all saiest of loves fervenceThat knowith he whom no
                    thing is hidde fro
CULGg617.Note: Ends imperfectly; some folios in the middle mutilated.
CULGg617.Attributed Author:
The vertuouse doctrine of Hoccleue vpon the rwle of princes (added
                    sixteenth century, top f. 1); Explicit liber de principum Regimine
                    (scribal, f. 90v)

CULHh411.First Lines:
MVsyng vpon the restles besinesseWhich this troubly world
                    haveþ in honde…
CULHh411.Last Lines:
…To þe þat all seest of loues feruenceAnd þat
                    knowiþ he þat noþing ys hyd fro
CULHh411.Attributed Author:
Occliue one of the t[ ]er[ ] & [ ] the father of ch[ ]slore (added top
                    margin, f. 1); The Authres name of this was Occlyue an acquaintaunce of Chaucer
                    as ye may red in the second Page of the 33 leaf of this verce & that he was
                    of the pryuy seale the same leaf the fyrst page of this [ ]re (added by
                    sixteenth-century hand, f. 96)

CULKk13.First Lines:
Mvs[ ] the restles busynesse[ ]his [ ] world hath ay in
                    honde…
CULKk13.Last Lines:
…To the that all seyiste of lovis servensThat knowith he whom
                    nothynge is hid fro
CULKk13.Attributed Title: H[ere] [be]ginneth a tretys wiche is callid [ ] (f. 1)

CamCCC496.First Lines:
Mvsyng opon þe restles besinesseWhich þat þis trubly
                    world hath ay in honde…
CamCCC496.Last Lines:
…To the þat all saist of luffis feruenceThat knowith whom
                    no thyng is hid fro
CamCCC496.Attributed Title:
Explicit liber iste qui vocatur Occhiffe de regimen principum &
                        constat magistro Willelmo Wilflete socio Aule de clare Cantabrigii qui eum
                        scribendo propriis manibus laborauit (f. 60v)

CamMagPep2101.First Lines:
Also ther is a nother newe getA fowle wast of cloth & an
                    excessif…
CamMagPep2101.Last Lines:
…he pees bade & whan he vnto heuen did styehe lefte pees
                    in erthe truly

CamQue12.First Lines:
Musyng vpon the restles besynesWich þat this troubly world
                    haþ ay on honde…
CamQue12.Last Lines:
…To the þat al seist of loues feruenceThat knoweth he
                    whom no þing is hid fro

CamStJohn223.First Lines:
MUsing vpon the resteles besynesseWhich þis troubly worlde
                    hath ay on honde…
CamStJohn223.Last Lines:
…And alle husbandes I pray and geve þem sorowThat to them
                    telle þer councelle even or morowe

CamTCC602.First Lines:
MVsinge vp on the restles besynesseWiche that þis trobuly
                    world hath ay on hondeThat other þing þanne froyt of
                    bittirnesse…
CamTCC602.Last Lines:
…To þe þat al seist of loues feruenceThat knoweth he
                    whom no thing is hid fro
CamTCC602.Attributed Author: Thomas hocclefe (added sixteenth century, top f. 111)

CamFitzMc182.First Lines:
…So flittynge is sche and so variauntThere is no triste on
                    hir faire lawȝyngeAftir gladde loke sche schapith hir to styngeI
                    was a drad soo of hir gerynesse…
CamFitzMc182.Last Lines:
…To the þat all seiste of loues feruenceThat knowith he
                    whome no þinge is hid froo
CamFitzMc182.Note: Begins imperfectly due to loss of folios.
CamFitzMc182.Attributed Title:
Explicit liber Egidii de regimine Principum translatum Per Occlyff
                    (f. 138)

CamFitzMc185.First Lines:
Musyng vpon the restles besynesseWhich this troubely world hath ay
                    on honde…
CamFitzMc185.Last Lines:
…To þe þat all seyst of Loves feruenceThat
                    knoweþ he who noþing is hid fro

BLAru38.First Lines:
Mosynge vp on the restlees bysynesseWhyche that thys troubly world
                    haþ ay on honde…
BLAru38.Last Lines:
…To the þat al seest of loues feruenceThat knowyth he
                    whom no þyng is hyd froo

BLAru59.First Lines:
[m]vsyng vpon the Resteles busynesWhiche that this troubly world
                    hath onhond…
BLAru59.Last Lines:
…To the that al seyst of loves feruenceThat knowith he that
                    nothyng is hid froo
BLAru59.Note:
Coat of arms in right margin of f. 1; the scribe is the so-called
                    ‘Hammond scribe’; ends, ‘Explicit’ (f.
                        89v) and a blank leaf between ff. 89 and 90.

BLHar116.First Lines:
Mvsyng opon þe restles bysynesWhiche þat þis world
                    hath ay on honde…
BLHar116.Last Lines:
…To the that alle seith of loues feruenceThat knoweth he whom
                    nothyng is hid fro

BLHar372.First Lines:
[M]ercy aftir the word of Seynt AustinOf hert is a verray
                    compassioun…
BLHar372.Last Lines:
…To the that al seist of loves feruenceThat knowith he that
                    nothyng is hyd fro
BLHar372.Note:
Beginning at line 3312. Written by the so-called ‘Hammond
                    scribe’ as a separate booklet from rest of the manuscript.
BLHar372.Attributed Author:
The author of this Treatise w[as] Thomas Hoccline Scholler to Geffrey
                    Chaucer (slip of paper bound in before f. 71, written in a hand of the sixteenth
                    century)
BLHar372.Attributed Title:
De Misericordia (f. 71); Hocklins Poems (written by a much later
                    hand at top of f. 71).

BLHar4826.First Lines:
MVsyng of the restlees besynesseWhich this troublþ wod ay hath
                    in honde…
BLHar4826.Last Lines:
…To the that al seyst of louys feruenceThat knowith he whoom
                    no thyng is hyd froo. Ihesu mercy

BLHar4866.First Lines: Mvsyng vpon the restles bisynesseWhich that this world hath ay on honde…
BLHar4866.Last Lines: …Of hevenes blysse that is endelesTo which yow brynge thauctour of pees
BLHar4866.Note: Heading “Heere begynnyth the Book how Pryncys sholden be governy” (f. 1, above text, rubric); ends “Amen,” then “Explicit” in rubric (f. 195v); first eight stanzas, on folio 1r-v, and last 5 lines at bottom of f. 195v written by a later hand to complete the text; medieval text begins f. 2 and ends f. 195v.

BLHar5977.First Lines:
To thyn egal concorde vnto thi fooSuffraunce and to thi self
                    holynesTo the nedy gredy with wrecchid woo…
BLHar5977.Last Lines:
Vnto his puple as plente and largesOf erthly good and better than is
                    reyneffallyng at euyn from heuyn thei seyne

BLHar7333.First Lines:
MVsing vp on the restlees besinesseWhich that this troubly wordle
                    hath ay in honde…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…I toke corage & whiles it was hootVn to my lorde the
                    prince thus I wrote…
BLHar7333.Note: Begins without incipit or title and ends at line 2016.

BLRoy8Axxi.Transcription:
With litill ffode content ys natureAnd beter þe bodi fareth with
                    a liteThen when it charged ys o[u]te of mesureLuke what thing may
                    þe body profiteAnd þe soule shall in þe same deliteWhat
                    thing it distempereth or disesethThe soule it hirteth for it gud
                    displesethWynes delicat & swete & strongeCauseth full
                    many an inconuentiseȜif þat a man outragly hem fongethei
                    biriyen wyt & fu[r]bede silenceOf counsell þei outrayen
                    pacienceThei kyndell yre & firen lecheryeAnd causen bothe bodi
                    & soule to die
BLRoy8Axxi.Note:
Extract, lines 3865-71 and 3830-36, added to first parchment flyleaf,
                    verso, by a hand of the late fifteenth or early sixteenth century.

BLRoy17Cxiv.First Lines:
Musynge vp on the resteles bysynesseWhich that this troubly world
                    hath ay in hande…
BLRoy17Cxiv.Last Lines:
…To the þat al [ ] of loues feruenceThat knowith [ ] whom
                    nothynge is hid fro
BLRoy17Cxiv.Note:
Damage to last few folios due to stain; followed by envoy to John of
                    Lancaster, Duke of Bedford ((6116).
BLRoy17Cxiv.Attributed Title:
Gilis de regimine principum (rubric in upper margin of f. 2, by
                    scribe); Here endeth the book of the gouernaunce of Princes that Thomas hoccleue
                    made whiche is a book of Moraltes and of vertues and hily dispreisinge
                    lewednesse and vices (f. 99v, rubric at end, by scribe)

BLRoy17Dvi.First Lines: Musyng vpon the restles besynesseThe which this troubly world hath ay on hond…
BLRoy17Dvi.Last Lines: …To the that all seest of loues seruenceThat knoweth he that no thyng is hidde fro

BLRoy17Dxviii.First Lines:
Musynge vpon the restelees bysynesseWhich that this troubly world
                    hath ay in handeÞat othir thyng than fruyt of bittirnesseNe
                    yildith naght as I can vndirstande …
BLRoy17Dxviii.Last Lines:
…To the þat al seist of loues feruenceThat knowith he
                    whom nothynge is hid fro

BLRoy17Dxix.First Lines:
Musynge vpon the restles besynesseWhiche that this troubli worlde
                    hath ay in honde…
BLRoy17Dxix.Last Lines:

Gilis de regimine principum (rubric in upper margin of f. 2, by

BLSl1212.First Lines:
[M]Osyng vp on the restlees bisynesseWhiche þat this world
                    hath ay on honde…
BLSl1212.Last Lines:
…to the þat al seith of loouys feruenceÞat knowith
                    he whom nothing is hid froo
BLSl1212.Note:
Ends, ‘Cest tout’ (f. 100), written by scribe. Scribe
                    identifies himself with large textura script at bottom of f. 100r, ‘Lucas
                    enduee 27’ [perhaps intended as ‘endure’]. The name also
                    appears beside other texts in the MS, numbers 275 and 3519.
BLSl1212.Attributed Title:
Thomas Hoccleve de regimine principis [sic] (added by
                    post-medieval hand to top margin, f. 5)

BLSl1825.First Lines:
MVsynge vpon the restelees busynessewiche þat this troubly
                    world haþ ay in honde…
BLSl1825.Last Lines:
…To the þat al seist of lovis fervenceThat knowith he
                    whom no þing is hid fro
BLSl1825.Note:
After last line, by hand of scribe, ‘Amen / Deo
                    gracias’ (f. 88).
BLSl1825.Attributed Title:
Hire bigynneth a tretys wiche that is callid (f. 2, rubric by scribe above
                    first line; not completed)

BLAdd18632.First Lines:
Mvsing vpon the restles besynessewich þat þis troubly
                    world haþ ay on honde…
BLAdd18632.Last Lines:
…to the that al seest of loues feruensthat knowith he whom

BLAdd18632.Attributed Title:
Explicit & cetera / Nunc fimen fixi penitet me so male / scripsi
                    (rubric by scribe after envoy, f. 99v); Explicit Hoccleue in
                        Aristotile & Egidio de regimine / Principum Et Jacobo de Cicile . S
                    Chesse (f. 99v, by scribe); followed by rubric heading Verba
                        Compilatoris ad librum (f. 99v, by scribe)

CovAcc3251.First Lines:
Musing vppon the Restles besinesseWhich that þis troubli
                    worlde hath ay on honde…
CovAcc3251.Last Lines:

EDU202.First Lines:
MVsynge vp on þe resteles besynesseWhich þat ys troubly
                    world haþ ay on honde…
EDU202.Last Lines:
…Thi doghter preye to beseche hir soneTo stynt of werres
                    þe dampnable wone…

SocAnt134.First Lines:

Chicago337.First Lines:
Mvsyng apon þe restles bisynesseWhiche þat þis world
                    hat ay on honde…

HunEL26A13.First Lines:
MUsyng vp on the restles besyneswiche that trowbli world hathe ay
                    on honde…
HunEL26A13.Last Lines:
…And if lust be to his magnyficenceDo be thi reed his welthes
                    shal witnesse
HunEL26A13.Note:
Ends, ‘Explicit liber de principium Regimine’ before
                    two-stanza envoy (f. 115); owned by ‘Aluredo Corneburgh de Camera
                    Regis’ (f. 115)

HunHM111.First Lines:
O litil book who yaf thee hardynesseThy wordes to pronounce in the
                    presence…
HunHM111.Last Lines:
…To thee þat al seist of loues feruenceÞat knowith
                    god whom no thyng is hid fro
HunHM111.Note: Envoy only (three stanzas of eight lines, ababbcbc).

Burrow,  John,  and  A. I. Doyle, eds.

EETS

PULGar137.First Lines:
mewsing vppon the resteles bysynesWhiche that this troble world
                    hath ay in hondeThat other thing than frute of bytternesNe yoldeth not
                    as y can vnder stonde…
PULGar137.Last Lines:
…Of heuen blesse that ys endelesThe whiche þou brynge the
                    autour of pees

PhilRos108330.First Lines:
MVsyng vp on the restles bisynesseWhich that this world hath ay on
                    honde…
PhilRos108330.Last Lines:
…Of hevenes blysse that is endelesTo which yow brynge
                    thauctour of pees
PhilRos108330.Note:
MS not foliated; f. 77 = sig. k.7; Followed by envoy (3 x 8-line
                    stanzas), ff. 77-77v, by another hand than main scribe: ‘A
                    [sic] lityl book who yaf the hardynesse / Thy wordys to pronounce in the

                    that no thyng is hid fro.’
